title: IBURD: Image Blending for Underwater Robotic Detection
author: Jungseok Hong (University of Minnesota-Twin Cities), Sakshi Singh (University of Minnesota-Twin Cities), Junaed Sattar (University of Minnesota-Twin Cities), ...
relevance_why: The paper presents a methodology for generating synthetic datasets for object detection that could inspire techniques for audio data augmentation in similar challenging environments.
background: Creating synthetic images to train models for detecting underwater debris, addressing challenges such as limited data and harsh conditions.
contribution: This paper introduces an image blending pipeline, IBURD, to solve the data scarcity problem in underwater detection, achieving improved detection performance through realistic synthetic image generation.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods focused on manual image collection or generative techniques that required extensive annotations.
technical_comparison.novelty: IBURD combines Poisson editing and style transfer to autonomously create high-quality synthetic images with pixel-level annotations efficiently.

key_innovation: The pipeline allows for blending transparent objects into complex underwater backgrounds without visual artifacts, enhancing the realism of synthetic data.
real_world_impact: This work enhances the capability of autonomous underwater vehicles by enabling effective computer vision training in challenging conditions, aiding environmental conservation efforts.
limitations: The authors mention the dependency on the quality and diversity of the source images used for blending.

new_terms.Poisson editing: **Poisson editing** is a technique for seamlessly blending image patches into an image by applying constraints on gradient fields, creating smooth transitions.
new_terms.style transfer: **Style transfer** is a method in computer vision that modifies an image to adopt the visual appearance of another image while preserving its core content.
